feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Business Application Studio
feed.subtitle: SAP Business Application Studio Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: How to Use NPM Modules Like crypto-js in SAPUI5 Using UI5 Tooling Modules
entry.content:
Use NPM Modules in SAPUI5 on Cloud Foundry with UI5 Tooling (crypto-js Example)

Ever wanted to use modern JavaScript libraries like crypto-js in your SAPUI5 project? You're in the right place.

With the help of ui5-tooling-modules, you can now seamlessly integrate NPM modules into your UI5 apps—no hacks or copy-pasting needed.

Let’s unlock powerful encryption, hashing, and token generation in a few simple steps! 🚀

Note: This method is designed for use inside controller files (or any AMD-style module). You cannot use require() or top-level import syntax like in standard Node.js or modern frontend frameworks.

Prerequisites

  • Node.js installed

  • SAPUI5/Fiori Tools CLI
  • UI5 Tooling v3

    Step 1: Create a Basic SAPUI5 Project

    Use the SAP Fiori Tools or Yeoman generator.

    • Template: Basic

    • Data Source: None
    • Attributes: Default

      Ensure index.html looks something like this:

       <script
                   id="sap-ui-bootstrap"
                  src="resources/sap-ui-core.js"
                  data-sap-ui-theme="sap_horizon"
                  data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{ "your.project.namespace":               "./" }'
                  data-sap-ui-         oninit="module:sap/ui/core/ComponentSupport"

                 data-sap-ui-async="true" data-sap-ui- frameOptions="trusted" /> 

       

      Step 2: Install ui5-tooling-modules

      In your project root:


      npm install --save-dev ui5-tooling-modules

      ✅UI5  Tooling v3 handles module resolution—no need to add ui5.dependencies manually.

    • 🔒Step 3: Install crypto-js


      npm install --save-dev crypto-js

    • Step 4: Use crypto-js in Your Controller

      You can now use the npm module in any controller like this: 

       

      sap.ui.define([
      "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
      "crypto-js/sha256"
      ], function(Controller, SHA256) {
      "use strict";
      return Controller.extend("your.project.namespace.controller.Main", { onInit: function () {
      var message = "Hello UI5!";
      var hash = SHA256(message).toString();
      console.log("SHA256 Hash:", hash);
               }
          });
      });
      Reminder: This pattern only works inside controllers or AMD modules. You cannot use npm modules globally in your app or with require() outside of SAPUI5’s module system.

      Step 5: Configure ui5.yaml

      builder:
            customTasks:
                        - name: ui5-tooling-modules-task
                           afterTask: replaceVersion
      server:
             customMiddleware:
                 - name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware                                             afterMiddleware: compression
                  - name: fiori-tools-proxy
                   afterMiddleware: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware

    • Step 6: Run and Test

      Start the app using:

      npm run start-noflp

      Open DevTools → Console. You should see the SHA256 hash logged.

       

      Why Use crypto-js in SAPUI5?

      • Modern encryption, hashing, and token generation

      • No external script tags or CDNs
      • Works natively with AMD modules in SAPUI5
      • TypeScript-friendly
      • Perfect for using NPM modules inside controllers

        Final Thoughts

        Thanks to ui5-tooling-modules, integrating npm packages like crypto-js is clean and stable. While it’s limited to controller (or AMD module) scope, that’s often enough for most enterprise UI logic.
        Whether you’re building internal tools or customer apps, this setup empowers you to use modern JS libraries safely within the SAPUI5 ecosystem.

entry.title: Transport process of BPA, BAS and IS projects in BTP
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I created Build Process Automation approval processes, Business Application Studio ui5 applications, and Integration Suite iFlows in BTP subaccount.

And I would like to transport these projects to test/PRD.

But since I'm new in BTP, I'm not so sure how to do it.

So, could you please advise which are the best practices to transport each of these projects?

And also, in BTP, dev/test/PRD means separated subaccounts?

Could you please answer my questions?

 

Thank You.

Best Regards,

Aye Chan

entry.title: Can We Bring “Import Financial Data” to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud? -Workflow Integration
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We have implemented a Project Budget Approval Enhancement in SAP Public Cloud leveraging SAP BTP services. As part of this solution, we created the Import Financial Data app within SAP Work Zone to trigger the budget approval workflow. Once the workflow is triggered, the data is seamlessly transferred to the SAP Public Cloud.

We would like to know if there is a way to replicate the Import Financial Data app directly within SAP Public Cloud, since the current app is only available in SAP Work Zone.

entry.title: "message": "Missing parameter: options" in SAP Document AI Upload API
entry.content:
Hi Team,

While working with the document upload api (below) in SAP document AI API from BAS 

../document-information-extraction/v1/document/jobs getting the error in network response -
{
"error": {
"code": "E95",
"message": "Required form-data not provided.",
"details": [
{
"code": "0",
"message": "Missing parameter: options"
}
]
}
}
while the same is working fine from Postman

Any help is greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance.

SAP Document AI

entry.title: BAS Connection to On-Premises System Failing with 'Request failed with status code 503'
entry.content:
Hello All,

I'm getting a The server returned an error. Request failed with status code 503 in SAP Business Application Studio when trying to connect to an on-premise system.

  • The system is connected successfully in Cloud Connector.

  • Destination is valid, and connection works in Build Apps , Business Automation Process.

  • BAS is the only place it's failing.

  • I have SAP_ALL access, and all required services are accessible as confirmed by  BASIS & SECURITY Team.

Did I miss any configuration on the on-premise system or in BAS? 

Also, is there a way to debug or trace this kind of issue from the BAS or backend side?

 

 

Additional Information:
When I performed the Fiori connection check to trace the issue, I encountered the following errors while establishing the connection in Business Application Studio (BAS):

  • OData V2 catalog service not available.

  • OData V4 catalog service not available.

  • Error: Cannot query V2 catalog service for DEV_001.

  • Error: Cannot query V4 catalog service for DEV_001.

 

 

Destination --> Check Connection

I'm completely new to the BAS application and would appreciate any guidance to help me understand and resolve this connection issue.

I am trying to develop UI5 app where First page routing parameter will come from SAP Build Work zone, standard edition application navigation parameters. But when I am defining route patterns in manifest.json file for first page It is showing blank on output screen. Here is code for manifest.json.

 "routes": [

  In workzone, standard edition I am giving navigation parameters like this.                                                           

Dashboard controller:- 

Can anybody help me on this, while passing parameter in manifest file I am not able to see anything and if I remove this I can see the output of app but can't fetch argument from onRouteMatched in this case. Any help would be appreciated.

entry.title: Client-Side DOCX to PDF Conversion in SAP BAS UI5 - Need Expert Guidance
entry.content:
I'm developing a UI5 application in SAP BAS that requires client-side DOCX-to-PDF conversion with placeholder replacement functionality. My current approach uses Mammoth.js to convert DOCX to HTML and jsPDF to generate PDFs, with successful placeholder replacement in the DOCX XML. While the basic functionality works, I'm facing several challenges with document fidelity.

The main issues I'm encountering include inconsistent spacing and formatting compared to the original DOCX, difficulty implementing consistent headers and footers on every page, content overlapping with footer areas instead of flowing to the next page, and images from the original DOCX not rendering properly in the generated PDF. I've tried various CSS configurations and jsPDF parameters but haven't achieved the desired document quality.

I'm constrained to a client-side only solution with no backend processing allowed, so I'm looking for guidance from UI5 and JavaScript experts who have successfully implemented similar functionality. Specifically, I need advice on CSS best practices for PDF-compatible HTML, optimal jsPDF configuration for enterprise documents, techniques for proper page break management, and any alternative client-side libraries that might provide better DOCX parsing and PDF generation quality.

Has anyone achieved high-quality client-side document conversion in UI5 that maintains the original DOCX formatting and layout? Any practical solutions or recommendations would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: External Resource for Trial Account in SAP BAS
entry.content:
Hello experts,

I am following the Learning Journey for Developing Full-Stack Applications Using Productivity Tools in SAP Business Application Studio  and I came across a problem when adding an external resource. There seems to be no sandbox available for Business Partner (A2X).

This is the learning resource I am currently following: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-full-stack-applications-using-productivity-tools-in-sap-business-application-studio/consuming-an-external-service-from-sap-s-4hana_faa318cd-9b48-48c4-b5fc-e6c205fb7685 

In Developing a Risk Management Application to Extend SAP S/4HANA > Consuming an External Service From SAP S/4HANA > Task 2

I was wondering if there is another way to do this. 

Regards,

Ley

entry.title: BAS Trial Subscription Failed after CIS_TECHNICAL Migration – Workspace Inaccessible
entry.content:
Plain Text mode

Hello,

My SAP BTP Trial SAP Business Application Studio subscription stopped working after an automated change done by CIS_TECHNICAL on 11 Aug 2025.

Details:
Subaccount ID: ffe73b4b-9e84-4013-8c44-ffe60aec8fcc
Region: Singapore (cf-ap12)
Created On: 11 Aug 2025
Changed On: 11 Aug 2025
Created By: CIS_TECHNICAL
Changed By: CIS_TECHNICAL
Status: Subscription Failed (Go to Application button disabled)
Workspace: I had an existing BAS workspace with project files before this migration.

It seems that during the automated migration or maintenance, my BAS subscription was recreated but failed to provision.
Now I cannot access my previous workspace, and the system will not let me open BAS.

SAP BTP

Trial Account

Request:
Please check if my previous workspace data still exists in the backend and if the subscription can be re-provisioned without deleting it, so I can recover my work.



Thank you.

entry.title: Create Your First AI-Powered App in SAP Build Code with Joule and Generative AI
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Generative AI is revolutionizing the way developers create applications, and SAP is at the forefront of this change. With tools like SAP Build Code and Joule, developers can dramatically speed up the entire development lifecycle — from designing data models to building intuitive user interfaces — achieving in minutes what once took weeks. This fusion of AI-powered intelligence and SAP’s enterprise-grade capabilities empowers teams to innovate faster, reduce manual effort, and deliver high-quality applications that drive real business value.

Step 1. Introduction to SAP Build Code and Joule

What is SAP Build Code?

SAP Build Code is part of the SAP Build family, enabling pro-code developers to:

  • Build clean-core compliant extensions
  • Use SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)
  • Leverage AI-assisted code generation via Joule
  • Integrate with both SAP and non-SAP systems

It’s deeply integrated into SAP BTP and offers:

  • A built-in development environment
  • Access to APIs and services
  • Security, CI/CD, and runtime tools
  • Fusion development — collaboration between professional developers and business experts

Why Clean Core Matters

A clean core keeps your SAP S/4HANA system as close to standard as possible, enabling:

  • Faster innovation adoption
  • Easier upgrades
  • Reduced total cost of ownership
  • Improved security and performance

SAP Build Code supports this by focusing on side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP.

Where Joule Fits In

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, helps you:

  • Generate CDS data models from natural language prompts
  • Build services, sample data, and annotations automatically
  • Add business logic without manually writing all boilerplate code
  • Create UI elements through guided wizards

Step 2. Building the Employee Skill Tracker Application

The session’s mission was to build a Finance Application in minutes using:

  • SAP Build Code for development
  • CAP model for backend logic
  • Joule for AI-driven code and UI generation

With just a natural language prompt, Joule generated the entities (Employee, Skill, Project, and Certification), their attributes, and associations. The CAP service layer and Fiori UI annotations were created automatically, enabling the team to jump straight into implementing business rules such as certification expiry alerts and skill-gap detection.

Application Overview

The application allows:

  • Creating employees, skills, projects, and certifications
  • Assigning skills to employees and tracking their proficiency levels
  • Allocating employees to projects and monitoring their start/end dates and status
  • Recording employee certifications with issuer details and expiry tracking
  • Automating business rules, such as flagging upcoming certification expiries or identifying employees with required skills for open projects

Step 3. Setting Up SAP Build Code

You can set up SAP Build Code in two main ways:

  1. Set-up the SAP Build and Business Studio using Service MarketPlace
  2. Booster in SAP BTP Cockpit – Works for trial and enterprise accounts.

For this session, the trial account + booster method was used:

Created a dedicated SAP BTP subaccount with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio (BAS).
All required roles, entitlements, and services—including CAP runtime, SAP HANA Cloud, and AI-powered Joule integration—were enabled automatically, ensuring a ready-to-develop environment without any manual setup overhead.

Step 4. Creating the Full-Stack Application

Flow 1: Starting a Project

  • In the SAP Build Lobby, select Create → Application → Full Stack Application

  • Name the project, link it to a BAS Dev Space, and open it in Business Application Studio

Initially, the Employee Skill Tracker project was a blank canvas — no entities, no business logic, and no UI. Within minutes, Joule transformed it into a fully structured CAP application, complete with data models, OData services, and Fiori-ready annotations.

Flow 2: Generating the Data Model with Joule

Using a natural language prompt, Joule generated:

Entities:

  1. Employee (Name, Email, Department, Hire Date)
  2. Skill (Skill Name, Proficiency Level)
  3. Project (Project Name, Start Date, End Date, Status)
  4. Certification (Certificate Name, Issuer, Expiry Date)

Result:

  1. schema.cds for entity definitions
  2. service.cds exposing OData services for Employee management
  3. Fiori annotations for displaying employee skill matrices in a table

Example prompt snippet:

"Create a CAP data model for an "Employee Skill Tracker" application.

Entities:

  1. Employee — Fields: Name (String), Email (String), Department (String), Hire Date (Date).
  2. Skill — Fields: Skill Name (String), Proficiency Level (String).
  3. Project — Fields: Project Name (String), Start Date (Date), End Date (Date), Status (String).
  4. Certification — Fields: Certificate Name (String), Issuer (String), Expiry Date (Date).

Requirements:

  1. Use UUID as the key for all entities.
  2. Create associations so that Skills, Projects, and Certifications link to an Employee.
  3. Generate schema.cds with entity definitions and associations.
  4. Generate service.cds exposing OData services for all entities.
  5. Add Fiori UI annotations for each entity to support List Reports and Object Pages.
  6. Use titles for fields in annotations to make the UI user-friendly."

Result:

  • schema.cds with entity definitions
  • service.cds with OData service exposure
  • Fiori annotations for UI hints

Flow 3: Adding Sample Data

From the data editor:

  • Added mock data for each entity
  • Enhanced it via Joule prompt:

"Generate data/EmployeeSkillTracker.csv sample data for my CAP application with the following entities and relationships:

  1. Employee — Fields: UUID key, Name, Email, Department, Hire Date.
  2. Skill — Fields: UUID key, Skill Name, Proficiency Level, Association to Employee.
  3. Project — Fields: UUID key, Project Name, Start Date, End Date, Status, Association to Employee.
  4. Certification — Fields: UUID key, Certificate Name, Issuer, Expiry Date, Association to Employee.

Requirements:

  1. Create 5 employees with realistic names, emails, departments, and hire dates.
  2. Assign 2–3 skills per employee with varying proficiency levels (Beginner, Intermediate, Expert).
  3. Assign 1–2 projects per employee with realistic start/end dates and statuses (Planned, Active, Completed).
  4. Assign 1–2 certifications per employee with different issuers and expiry dates.
  5. Output data in CSV format compatible with CAP db/data folder.
  6. Ensure associations match using Employee UUID values."

Outcome: Meaningful, test-ready datasets.

Flow 4: Implementing Business Logic

With the core entities — Employee, Skill, Project, and Certification — in place, the next step was to add custom business logic that makes the Employee Skill Tracker truly useful.

Requirements:

  1. In the srv/employee-service.js, add the following rules:

  • Auto-assign “Onboarding” project to every new Employee when they are created, with Status = "Active" and Start Date = current date.
  • Prevent deletion of Employees if they have active projects. Show an error: "Cannot delete employee with active projects".
  • Validate Skill Proficiency Level so it must be one of: "Beginner", "Intermediate", "Expert". If not, reject with a meaningful message.
  • Auto-calculate Project Status: if the End Date is before today, set Status to "Completed".
  • Send a console log every time a new Certification is added for an Employee.

  1. Ensure logic uses CAP Node.js event handlers (before, after, on) appropriately.

  2. Output the complete srv/employee-service.js file with the implemented logic.

Joule wrote the JavaScript for these logic files directly from the prompt.

Once you click the Add button, the “Open Code Editor” option becomes visible. From here, you can leverage Joule to generate the required business logic automatically. With just a natural language prompt, Joule translates your intent into CAP service code — exactly like in the screenshot below — saving time on boilerplate and letting you focus on fine-tuning the rules.

Flow 5: Building the UI

With the backend logic ready, it was time to create an intuitive and connected user interface.

Using the SAP Build Code UI Wizard, we:

  • Generated a Fiori Elements List Report for the Employee entity to provide an at-a-glance view of all employees in the system.
  • Enabled navigation links from each employee record to their associated Skills, Projects, and Certifications, ensuring a seamless drill-down experience.
  • Configured key columns in the list report, including Department, Hire Date, and Total Skills, for quick decision-making.
  • Applied Fiori Annotations for better formatting — e.g., date pickers for Hire Date, semantic colors for project status, and quick badges for expiring certifications.

Step 5. Running the App

After dependencies installed:

  • Backend OData services and frontend UI were available instantly
  • UI showed customer list, purchases, and redemptions
  • Business logic executed when adding purchases or redemptions (reward points updated automatically)

Step 6. Key Takeaways

  • Speed: Built an Employee Skill Tracker app from scratch to a functional CAP + Fiori app in under 15 minutes using Joule-generated entities (Employee, Skill, Project, Certification).
  • AI Boost: Joule eliminated boilerplate coding, allowing the developer to focus on business logic, such as auto-generating unique Skill IDs to avoid duplicate key errors.
  • Clean Core: Entire solution is side-by-side on SAP BTP; no modifications to the core S/4HANA system, ensuring upgrade safety.
  • Scalability: Easily extendable—can add features like Skill Gap Analysis, automatic Certification Expiry alerts, or integration with S/4HANA HR and SuccessFactors for real-time employee data sync.
  • Resilience: Built-in safeguards like UUID-based keys or ID auto-generation logic prevent data conflicts and ensure smooth multi-user usage.
  • Future-Ready: Can quickly expand to mobile apps, integrate with SAP Build Process Automation for skill approval workflows, or hook into SAP Analytics Cloud for skill heatmaps.

Conclusion
Generative AI, coupled with SAP’s robust development ecosystem, is transforming how enterprise-grade applications are built. In this journey from concept to a fully functional Finance App, SAP Build Code and Joule demonstrated how AI can eliminate repetitive tasks, accelerate delivery, and uphold clean-core principles.

What once took weeks of manual coding, data modeling, and UI design now takes minutes—without compromising quality, scalability, or integration capabilities. By combining pro-code flexibility, AI-assisted development, and SAP BTP’s enterprise foundation, teams can focus on solving real business challenges instead of wrestling with technical overhead.

This is more than a productivity boost—it’s a new paradigm for how innovation happens in the SAP landscape.

entry.title: Manual Export/Import vs Cloud Transport Management Service to transport BTP projects
entry.content:
Hi experts, 

I'm confusing which method is better between manual export/import and Cloud Transport Management Service to transport BTP projects like Build Process Automation approval workflows, Business Application Studio ui5 apps and Integration Suite iflows.

I checked some blogs and it is recommended to use Cloud Transport Management Service instead manual export/import.

By using Cloud Transport Management Service, there are advantages like Manual effort (no need to reconfigure everything), Less error-prone and so on.

So, I tried to transport one of my BPA approval process by using both methods.

And the results are same.

I needed to reconfigure the same steps for both methods.

There is no difference between them and using cTMS is more complex for me because there is initial set up and additional cost too.

 

So, could you please explain details why and when cTMS should be used, in details?

 

Thank You.

Aye Chan

Thanks

entry.title: Business Application Studio Cannot See BTP Destinations (Platform Issue)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am facing a persistent issue where my Business Application Studio dev space is unable to see a BTP destination I've configured. The destination itself is set up correctly and the connection to my on-premise system is working perfectly, but it does not appear in the Fiori generator.

Environment:

  • BTP Environment: Trial Account

  • Region: US East (VA) - AWS

  • BAS Dev Space Type: SAP Fiori

Summary of the situation:

  1. I have successfully installed and configured the SAP Cloud Connector.

  2. I have created a destination in my BTP subaccount that connects to my on-premise SAP system. This destination has the required properties: HTML5.DynamicDestination = true and WebIDEUsage = odata_gen.

  3. Crucially, when I click the "Check Connection" button for this destination in the BTP Cockpit, the check is successful and returns a "200 OK - Backend is reachable" message. This confirms the entire end-to-end connection is working correctly.

  4. However, when I go into a Business Application Studio dev space and use the SAP Fiori generator, this destination does not appear in the "System" dropdown list.

  5. I have tried restarting the dev space, which did not solve the issue. I then deleted the dev space and created a brand new "SAP Fiori" dev space, and the destination is still not visible.

  6. When I run the diagnostic command npx fiori-tools destination in the terminal of the new dev space, I receive a DNS error:

    npm ERR! code ENOTFOUND
npm ERR! syscall getaddrinfo
npm ERR! errno ENOTFOUND
npm ERR! request to https://.../_.../destinations failed, reason: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND ...

This ENOTFOUND error in a brand new dev space, combined with the successful connection check in the cockpit, strongly suggests a platform-level DNS or networking issue within the BAS environment for my trial account.

Could you please advise if this is a known issue or what the next steps should be? I believe I have exhausted all possible configuration and troubleshooting steps.

Thank you for your help.

entry.title: Handling Deep Insert with Navigation Properties in Fiori Elements Using annotation.xml and manifest.
entry.content:
I am using Fiori Elements' List Report and Object Page to create new data via API_PRODUCT_SRV using a POST request. Although I have created the data, I encounter an error because it seems necessary to also send the to_Description data. I am trying to send the following payload:

{
"Product": "DUMMY_PRODUCT",
"ProductType": "FERT",
"BaseUnit": "EA",
"to_Description": {
"Product": "DUMMY_PRODUCT",
"Language": "EN",
"ProductDescription": "test API"
}
}

When updating existing data, the Description field appears on the screen, but it does not appear during creation. So, I cannot include the "to_Description" data  in the payload. I believe this is because the Product does not yet exist, so the Description cannot be linked. Is this correct?

Since I am using a standard API, I would like to use annotation.xml and manifest.json instead of CDS View annotations to include to_Description data. How should I write these files?

entry.title: Disable VizFrame default popover on data selection
entry.content:
I recently faced an issue while working with a VizFrame chart in SAPUI5.
My requirement was to disable/remove the default popover that appears when clicking on a data point in the chart.

Viz:VizFrame uiConfig="{applicationSet:'fiori'}"  id="VizChart"  vizType="column" 

After adding this Property, the default popover was removed automatically.

so question is Why Popover is Removed ?
Because in Fiori mode, SAP expects you to use your own popover or SmartPopover instead of the Viz standard one. That’s why the standard tooltip/popover is gone when you add this.

entry.title: Issue with upload:UploadSet in custom UI5 application after upgrade
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

Recently we have upgraded our HANA system from 2020 to 2023 and found that the issue related to upload. 

After clicking on upload button and attached file, we are getting the below progress bar with pending state though it got uploaded.

 

In our code afterItemAdded we are calling one function and we have set the visibility as false like below 

 

 

How ever still the Progressbar is coming, the same code is working fine non upgraded system. 

Do i need to change any property here to make it work in 2023 version ? please throw some light on this issue.

 

KR,

Anji
